**Faith No More** (sometimes abbreviated as **FNM**) is an American
[rock](/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music") band from [San
Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"), [California](/wiki/California
"California"), formed in 1979.[1] Before settling on their current name in
1982, the band performed under the names Sharp Young Men[1] and later Faith No
Man.[2] Bassist [Billy Gould](/wiki/Billy_Gould "Billy Gould") and drummer
[Mike Bordin](/wiki/Mike_Bordin "Mike Bordin") are the longest remaining
members of the band, having been involved with Faith No More since its
inception. The band underwent several lineup changes early in their career,
along with some major changes later on. The current lineup of Faith No More
consists of Gould, Bordin, keyboardist/rhythm guitarist [Roddy
Bottum](/wiki/Roddy_Bottum "Roddy Bottum"), lead guitarist [Jon
Hudson](/wiki/Jon_Hudson "Jon Hudson") and vocalist/lyricist [Mike
Patton](/wiki/Mike_Patton "Mike Patton").

After releasing six studio albums, including their best-selling records _[The
Real Thing](/wiki/The_Real_Thing_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "The Real Thing
\(Faith No More album\)")_ (1989) and _[Angel
Dust](/wiki/Angel_Dust_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "Angel Dust \(Faith No More
album\)")_ (1992),[3] Faith No More officially announced their breakup on
April 20, 1998. They have since reunited, embarked on [The Second Coming
Tour](/wiki/The_Second_Coming_Tour "The Second Coming Tour") from 2009 to
2012, and released their seventh studio album, _[Sol
Invictus](/wiki/Sol_Invictus_\(album\) "Sol Invictus \(album\)")_ , in May
2015.[4]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

### Early days
(1979–1984)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early days \(1979–1984\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Chuck_Mosley.jpg/150px-
Chuck_Mosley.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chuck_Mosley.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chuck_Mosley.jpg "Enlarge")

Vocalist [Chuck Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley") joined Faith No
More in 1983, and during his five-year tenure with the band, he appeared on
their first two studio albums.

Faith No More was originally formed as Sharp Young Men in 1979 by bassist
[Billy Gould](/wiki/Billy_Gould "Billy Gould"), drummer [Mike
Bordin](/wiki/Mike_Bordin "Mike Bordin"), vocalist Mike Morris, and
keyboardist Wade Worthington. Mike Morris described the name as "a piss-take
on all the ‘elegant’ groups at the time."[5] Later on, Morris proposed the
name Faith In No Man, but, eventually, the band settled on Bordin's suggestion
Faith No Man (stylized as Faith. No Man).[5]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/64/Faith_no_more_logo.png)](/wiki/File:Faith_no_more_logo.png)

[](/wiki/File:Faith_no_more_logo.png "Enlarge")

The band's classic logo, used on their 1985 debut _We Care a Lot_. It was
originally designed by Billy Gould as an homage to the [Symbol of
Chaos](/wiki/Symbol_of_Chaos "Symbol of Chaos").[6]

They recorded "[Quiet in Heaven/Song of
Liberty](/wiki/Quiet_in_Heaven/Song_of_Liberty "Quiet in Heaven/Song of
Liberty")", released in 1983. The songs were recorded in [Matt
Wallace](/wiki/Matt_Wallace "Matt Wallace")'s parents' garage, where Wallace
had set up and been running a recording studio while the band was still
recording under the name Sharp Young Men,[7] with Mike Morris, Billy Gould,
Mike Bordin and Wade Worthington. Worthington left shortly thereafter. They
changed their name to Faith No Man for the release of the single, which
featured two of the three songs recorded in Wallace's garage,[8] and hired
Roddy Bottum to replace Worthington. Bottum, Gould and Bordin quit the band
shortly after and formed Faith No More. They chose the name to accentuate the
fact that "The Man" (Mike Morris) was "No More". They didn't have any constant
guitarists or vocalists until they eventually settled on [Chuck
Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley") in 1983 and later [Jim
Martin](/wiki/Jim_Martin_\(musician\) "Jim Martin \(musician\)").[9]

### _We Care a Lot_ and _Introduce Yourself_
(1985–1988)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: We Care a Lot and Introduce Yourself \(1985–1988\)")]

After the name change, the band initially started recording _We Care a Lot_
without backing from a [record label](/wiki/Record_label "Record label") and,
after pooling their money, recorded five songs. This gained the attention of
Ruth Schwartz, who was then forming the independent label [Mordam
Records](/wiki/Mordam_Records "Mordam Records"), under which the band, after
getting the necessary financial support, finished and released the album. It
was the first official release for both the band and the label.[10]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Why Do You Bother" (1985)](/wiki/File:Faith_No_More_Why_Do_you_Bother_Sample.ogg "File:Faith No More Why Do you Bother Sample.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/7/70/Faith_No_More_Why_Do_you_Bother_Sample.ogg) 30 second sample of the _We Care a Lot_ song "Why Do You Bother".

* * *

_Problems playing this file? See[media help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help
"Wikipedia:Media help")._  
  
In late 1986, Faith No More was signed to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los
Angeles") label [Slash Records](/wiki/Slash_Records "Slash Records") by Anna
Statman.[11] The label had recently been sold to the [Warner Music
Group](/wiki/Warner_Music_Group "Warner Music Group") subsidiary [London
Records](/wiki/London_Records "London Records"), ensuring a widespread release
for the band's following albums. _[Introduce
Yourself](/wiki/Introduce_Yourself "Introduce Yourself")_ was released in
1987, and a revamped version of their debut album's title track "[We Care a
Lot](/wiki/We_Care_a_Lot_\(song\) "We Care a Lot \(song\)")" saw minor success
on MTV. Mosley's behaviour had started to become increasingly erratic,
particularly during a troubled tour of Europe in 1988. Incidents include him
allegedly punching Billy Gould on stage,[12] the release party for the album
_Introduce Yourself_ — during which he fell asleep on stage — and one of
Mosley's roadies getting into a fist fight with guitarist Jim Martin during
the European tour.[13][12] Mosley was eventually fired after the band returned
home from Europe. Billy Gould reflected "There was a certain point when I went
to rehearsal, and Chuck wanted to do all acoustic guitar songs. It was just so
far off the mark. The upshot was that I got up, walked out and quit the band.
I Just said: ‘I’m done – I can’t take this any longer. It’s just so
ridiculous’. The same day, I talked to Bordin, and he said: ‘Well, I still
want to play with you’. Bottum did the same thing. It was another one of these
‘firing somebody without firing them’ scenarios."[12]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/ca/FNM_PP_TRT.jpg/220px-
FNM_PP_TRT.jpg)](/wiki/File:FNM_PP_TRT.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FNM_PP_TRT.jpg "Enlarge")

Faith No More in a promotional photo for _[The Real
Thing](/wiki/The_Real_Thing_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "The Real Thing \(Faith No
More album\)")_ , c. 1989-1990

### Mike Patton joins and _The Real Thing_
(1989–1991)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Mike Patton joins and The Real Thing \(1989–1991\)")]

Chuck Mosley was replaced with singer [Mike Patton](/wiki/Mike_Patton "Mike
Patton") in 1988. Patton, who was singing with his high school band, [Mr.
Bungle](/wiki/Mr._Bungle "Mr. Bungle"), was recruited at Martin's suggestion
after he heard a demo of Mr. Bungle.[14] According to Patton, he first met the
band during a 1986 gig at "a pizza parlour" in his hometown of [Eureka,
California](/wiki/Eureka,_California "Eureka, California").[15] Two weeks
after joining Faith No More, he had written all the lyrics for the songs that
would make up the Grammy award-nominated _[The Real
Thing](/wiki/The_Real_Thing_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "The Real Thing \(Faith No
More album\)")_.[16]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Epic" (1989)](/wiki/File:FNM_Epic_Sample.ogg "File:FNM Epic Sample.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/1f/FNM_Epic_Sample.ogg) 30 second sample from Faith No More's "Epic".

"[Epic](/wiki/Epic_\(Faith_No_More_song\) "Epic \(Faith No More song\)")" was
released in January 1990 and was a top 10 hit. The music video for "Epic"
received extensive [airplay](/wiki/Airplay_\(radio\) "Airplay \(radio\)") on
MTV in 1990, despite anger from [animal rights](/wiki/Animal_rights "Animal
rights") activists for a [slow motion](/wiki/Slow_motion "Slow motion") shot
of a fish flopping out of water.[17][18] That same year, Faith No More
performed at the [1990 MTV Video Music
Awards](/wiki/1990_MTV_Video_Music_Awards "1990 MTV Video Music Awards")
(September 6) and on the 293rd episode of _[Saturday Night
Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ (December 1)[19][20]
"[From Out of Nowhere](/wiki/From_Out_of_Nowhere_\(song\) "From Out of Nowhere
\(song\)")" and "[Falling to Pieces](/wiki/Falling_to_Pieces "Falling to
Pieces")" saw releases as singles, and a cover of [Black
Sabbath](/wiki/Black_Sabbath "Black Sabbath")'s "[War Pigs](/wiki/War_Pigs
"War Pigs")" was also produced for non-vinyl releases. In 1990, the band went
on an extensive US tour, sending _The Real Thing_ to Platinum status in
Canada, the US, and South America. The album also had big sales numbers in
Australia, UK, and the rest of Europe, pushing the total sales well above 4
million worldwide.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Mike_patton.jpg/200px-
Mike_patton.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mike_patton.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mike_patton.jpg "Enlarge")

Vocalist [Mike Patton](/wiki/Mike_Patton "Mike Patton") joined Faith No More
in 1988, replacing [Chuck Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley").

In February 1991, Faith No More released their only official live album,
_[Live at the Brixton
Academy](/wiki/You_Fat_Bastards:_Live_at_the_Brixton_Academy "You Fat
Bastards: Live at the Brixton Academy")_. The album also included two
previously unreleased studio tracks, "The Grade" and "The Cowboy Song". That
same year, the band contributed a track for the [motion picture
soundtrack](/wiki/Bill_%26_Ted%27s_Bogus_Journey:_Music_from_the_Motion_Picture
"Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey: Music from the Motion Picture") to _[Bill& Ted's
Bogus Journey](/wiki/Bill_%26_Ted%27s_Bogus_Journey "Bill & Ted's Bogus
Journey")_ with the song "The Perfect Crime". Jim Martin also made a brief
cameo in the film as "Sir James Martin" as the head of the "Faith No More
Spiritual and Theological Center". Mike Patton's original band [Mr.
Bungle](/wiki/Mr._Bungle "Mr. Bungle") would go on to sign with
[Slash](/wiki/Slash_Records "Slash Records")/[London](/wiki/London_Records
"London Records")'s parent label [Warner Bros.
Records](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Records "Warner Bros. Records") in 1991, following
the worldwide success of _The Real Thing_.[21]

### _Angel Dust_
(1992–1994)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Angel Dust \(1992–1994\)")]

Faith No More displayed an even more [experimental](/wiki/Experimental_music
"Experimental music") effort on their next album, _[Angel
Dust](/wiki/Angel_Dust_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "Angel Dust \(Faith No More
album\)")_. One critic writes that the album is "one of the more complex and
simply confounding records ever released by a major label"[22] and another
writes that the single "'A Small Victory', which seems to run [Madame
Butterfly](/wiki/Madame_Butterfly "Madame Butterfly") through
[Metallica](/wiki/Metallica "Metallica") and [Nile Rodgers](/wiki/Nile_Rodgers
"Nile Rodgers") (...) reveals a developing facility for combining unlikely
elements into startlingly original concoctions."[23]

Aside from "[A Small Victory](/wiki/A_Small_Victory_\(song\) "A Small Victory
\(song\)")" (which received a nomination for [Best Art
Direction](/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award_for_Best_Art_Direction "MTV Video Music
Award for Best Art Direction") at the [MTV Video Music
Awards](/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Awards "MTV Video Music Awards")), the tracks
"[Midlife Crisis](/wiki/Midlife_Crisis "Midlife Crisis")" and "[Everything's
Ruined](/wiki/Everything%27s_Ruined "Everything's Ruined")" were also released
as singles. The album included a re-recording of the [theme](/wiki/Theme_music
"Theme music") to the film _[Midnight Cowboy](/wiki/Midnight_Cowboy "Midnight
Cowboy")_ , and later pressings included a cover of [The
Commodores](/wiki/The_Commodores "The Commodores")
"[Easy](/wiki/Easy_\(Commodores_song\) "Easy \(Commodores song\)")", which in
some parts of the world became the band's biggest hit. _Angel Dust_ , though
not as successful as _The Real Thing_ in the US, sold 665,000 copies there,
and managed to outsell _The Real Thing_ in many other countries. In Germany,
the record was certified Gold for sales of more than 250,000 copies. The album
also matched the sales of _The Real Thing_ in Canada (Platinum), Australia
(Gold), and surpassed it in the Netherlands, France, Russia, and the UK.
Worldwide sales are around 3.1 million copies.

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Midlife Crisis" (1992)](/wiki/File:FNM_Midlife_Crisis_Sample.ogg "File:FNM Midlife Crisis Sample.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/5/53/FNM_Midlife_Crisis_Sample.ogg) 30 second sample from Faith No More's "MidLife Crisis".

After touring to support _Angel Dust_ in the summer of 1993, long-time
guitarist [Jim Martin](/wiki/%22Big%22_Jim_Martin ""Big" Jim Martin") left the
band due to internal conflicts. He was reportedly unhappy with the band's
change in musical direction on _Angel Dust_ , describing it as "gay
[disco](/wiki/Disco "Disco")".[24] According to Roddy Bottum, Martin was fired
via fax.[25] However, Martin himself states it was his decision to leave.[26]
Both [Godflesh](/wiki/Godflesh "Godflesh") guitarist [Justin
Broadrick](/wiki/Justin_Broadrick "Justin Broadrick") and [Killing
Joke](/wiki/Killing_Joke "Killing Joke") guitarist [Geordie
Walker](/wiki/Geordie_Walker "Geordie Walker") were reportedly offered to join
Faith No More after Martin's departure, but declined to join.[27] The position
was filled by Mike Patton's bandmate from Mr. Bungle, [Trey
Spruance](/wiki/Trey_Spruance "Trey Spruance"), who left soon after recording
1995's _[King for a Day... Fool for a
Lifetime](/wiki/King_for_a_Day..._Fool_for_a_Lifetime "King for a Day... Fool
for a Lifetime")_ and just before the band was to begin their world tour.
Spruance was replaced by [Dean Menta](/wiki/Dean_Menta "Dean Menta"), the
band's keyboard tech.

### _King for a Day..._ , _Album of the Year_ and break-up
(1995–1998)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: King for a Day..., Album of the Year and break-up
\(1995–1998\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/20/14063-KillingforaDayFoolforaLifetime20150903-3-1w6u22p.png)](/wiki/File:14063-KillingforaDayFoolforaLifetime20150903-3-1w6u22p.png)

[](/wiki/File:14063-KillingforaDayFoolforaLifetime20150903-3-1w6u22p.png
"Enlarge")

The alternate "barking dog logo", based on the artwork for Faith No More's
1995 album _King for a Day... Fool for a Lifetime_

1995's _[King for a Day... Fool for a
Lifetime](/wiki/King_for_a_Day..._Fool_for_a_Lifetime "King for a Day... Fool
for a Lifetime")_ varies greatly from song to song in style; [post-
hardcore](/wiki/Post-hardcore "Post-hardcore")/[punk](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk
rock"), [country](/wiki/Country_music "Country music"), [jazz](/wiki/Jazz
"Jazz"), [bossa nova](/wiki/Bossa_nova "Bossa nova"), [thrash
metal](/wiki/Thrash_metal "Thrash metal"), [gospel music](/wiki/Gospel_music
"Gospel music"), along with other signature FNM elements, are woven together
throughout the album. Singles included "[Digging the
Grave](/wiki/Digging_the_Grave "Digging the Grave")",
"[Evidence](/wiki/Evidence_\(Faith_No_More_song\) "Evidence \(Faith No More
song\)")", and "[Ricochet](/wiki/Ricochet_\(Faith_No_More_song\) "Ricochet
\(Faith No More song\)")". The album featured Mr. Bungle's [Trey
Spruance](/wiki/Trey_Spruance "Trey Spruance") on guitar. The record went Gold
in the UK, Australia, New Zealand, Netherlands and Germany, which gave the
album a respectable sales figure of around 1.5 million copies; this was
significantly lower than sales of their previous albums. A 7 x 7-inch box set
of singles was released, which included the B-sides and some interviews
between the songs.

_[Album of the Year](/wiki/Album_of_the_Year_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "Album of
the Year \(Faith No More album\)")_ was released in 1997 and featured yet
another new guitarist, Jon Hudson, who was a former roommate of Billy Gould.
The album debuted much higher than expected in some countries (for example, in
Germany, the album debuted at No. 2 and stayed in the chart for 5 months). In
Australia, _Album of the Year_ went to No. 1 and was certified Platinum. The
album charted in many countries in Europe. To date,[_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] _Album of
the Year_ has sold around 2 million copies worldwide. The singles "[Ashes to
Ashes](/wiki/Ashes_to_Ashes_\(Faith_No_More_song\) "Ashes to Ashes \(Faith No
More song\)")" and "[Last Cup of Sorrow](/wiki/Last_Cup_of_Sorrow "Last Cup of
Sorrow")" had minimal success (notably, the music video for "Last Cup of
Sorrow", which featured actress [Jennifer Jason
Leigh](/wiki/Jennifer_Jason_Leigh "Jennifer Jason Leigh"), was inspired by the
[Alfred Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred Hitchcock") film
_[Vertigo](/wiki/Vertigo_\(film\) "Vertigo \(film\)")_).
"[Stripsearch](/wiki/Stripsearch_\(song\) "Stripsearch \(song\)")" was
released as a single in various countries (excluding the US and UK). The album
received largely negative reviews from US-based critics at the time. _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ magazine wrote in their original
review "[They] are floundering around desperately, groping for a sense of
identity and direction in a decade that clearly finds them irrelevant",[28]
while _[Pitchfork Media](/wiki/Pitchfork_Media "Pitchfork Media")_ stated
"_Album Of The Year_ leaves one feeling like waking up and finding last
night's used condom -- sure, the ride was fun while it lasted, but what
remains is just plain icky. And you definitely don't want it in your CD
player."[29]

In early 1998, rumors of Faith No More's imminent demise began. Starting with
a rumor posted to the Faith No More [newsgroup](/wiki/Newsgroup "Newsgroup")
alt.music.faith-no-more claiming Mike Patton had quit the band in favor of
side projects, this rumor, although denied at the time, proved to be at least
partly true. Faith No More played their last show in Lisbon, Portugal on April
7, 1998.[16] The band cancelled their planned support tour for
[Aerosmith](/wiki/Aerosmith "Aerosmith") and on April 20, Billy Gould released
a statement by email and fax, saying "[T]he decision among the members is
mutual" and "the split will now enable each member to pursue his individual
project(s) unhindered." The band "thank[ed] all of those fans and associates
that have stuck with and supported the band throughout its history."

Immediately after the dissolution of Faith No More, the members went on to
numerous different projects. Mike Patton notably co-founded the supergroups
[Fantômas](/wiki/Fant%C3%B4mas_\(band\) "Fantômas \(band\)") and
[Tomahawk](/wiki/Tomahawk_\(band\) "Tomahawk \(band\)") in 1998-99, as well as
continuing his original band [Mr. Bungle](/wiki/Mr._Bungle "Mr. Bungle"), who
were still signed with [Warner Bros. Records](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Records
"Warner Bros. Records"). The sound of Tomahawk in particular has often been
compared to Faith No More's mid-late 1990s output.[30][31]

When Faith No More was brought up in a 1999 interview with _[The A.V.
Club](/wiki/The_A.V._Club "The A.V. Club")_ , Patton (then fronting [Mr.
Bungle](/wiki/Mr._Bungle "Mr. Bungle")) stated "I'm definitely glad it's over:
It was a great thing while it lasted, but it really had to end. I think if it
had continued it would have gotten really ugly. No fistfights or bloody noses
or anything like that, but the music would have been substandard. So the line
must be drawn there."[32] In another interview from 2001, he similarly stated
that the band had broken up "because we were starting to make bad music."[33]
However, Gould did not share the same sentiment as Patton on the quality of
the band's late material, stating in 1998 "However many records we sold or
didn't, we maintained over a long period of time a high standard of music that
we're proud of, and we never sucked. Whatever shit that happened to us on the
way, thank God it didn't get in the way of the music."[34]

### Reformation
(2009–2012)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reformation \(2009–2012\)")]

Rumours that Faith No More would reunite for shows in the
[UK](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") in the summer of 2009 were
circulating in late November 2008,[35] but were originally dismissed by
bassist Billy Gould. He explained: "If anything like this were to happen, it
would have to come from the band, and I haven't spoken with any of them in
over a year. So as far as I know, there isn't anything to talk about, and I'm
pretty sure that if you were to contact Patton, he would tell you the same
thing."[36]

However, on February 24, 2009 after months of speculation and rumors, Faith No
More announced they would be reforming with a line-up identical to the _[Album
of the Year](/wiki/Album_of_the_Year_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "Album of the
Year \(Faith No More album\)")_ era,[37] embarking on a reunion tour called
_[The Second Coming Tour](/wiki/The_Second_Coming_Tour "The Second Coming
Tour")_. To coincide with the band's reunion tour, Rhino released the sixth
Faith No More compilation, _[The Very Best Definitive Ultimate Greatest Hits
Collection](/wiki/The_Very_Best_Definitive_Ultimate_Greatest_Hits_Collection
"The Very Best Definitive Ultimate Greatest Hits Collection")_ , a double
album that includes their hit singles and b sides & rarities, in the UK on
June 8.[38] Faith No More then played in major European festivals including
[Download Festival](/wiki/Download_Festival "Download Festival") in the UK in
June, [Hurricane](/wiki/Hurricane_Festival "Hurricane Festival") and
[Southside](/wiki/Southside_Festival "Southside Festival") festivals in
Germany,[39] [Greenfield Festival](/wiki/Greenfield_Festival "Greenfield
Festival") in [Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland"),[40] [Hove
Festival](/wiki/Hove_Festival "Hove Festival") in [Norway](/wiki/Norway
"Norway") and [Roskilde Festival](/wiki/Roskilde_Festival "Roskilde Festival")
in [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark"),[41] among other dates. The tour
continued into 2010 with appearances at the [Soundwave
Festival](/wiki/Soundwave_\(Australian_music_festival\) "Soundwave
\(Australian music festival\)") in [Australian](/wiki/Australia "Australia")
cities throughout February and March.[42] During their tour, the band added
covers to their repertoire including "[Switch](/wiki/The_Scream_\(album\) "The
Scream \(album\)")" by [Siouxsie and the
Banshees](/wiki/Siouxsie_and_the_Banshees "Siouxsie and the Banshees").[43]

After an eleven-month hiatus, Faith No More played four shows in South America
in November 2011. On the first date (November 8, 2011), the band played a
"mystery song," which led to speculation of new material.[44] They played
Sonisphere France on July 7, 2012.[45] Following several more shows in Europe
during 2012, Faith No More became temporarily inactive again. Mike Patton
spent 2013 touring with his reformed rock supergroup
[Tomahawk](/wiki/Tomahawk_\(band\) "Tomahawk \(band\)"),[46] while the band's
other members also pursued their own side projects. In July 2013, Billy Gould
confirmed that the band's hiatus would not be permanent, saying "We will do
something again only when all members are with the focus on that, and ready
for the challenge. This is not the time... yet."[47]

### _Sol Invictus_ and hiatus
(2015–present)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Sol Invictus and hiatus \(2015–present\)")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Black Friday" (2015)](/wiki/File:Faith_No_More_Black_Friday_sample.ogg "File:Faith No More Black Friday sample.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/0b/Faith_No_More_Black_Friday_sample.ogg) 30 second sample of the _Sol Invictus_ song "Black Friday".

"Wikipedia:Media help")._  
  
On May 29, 2014, Faith No More posted a message (along with a photograph of
Mike Patton) on their Twitter account, saying that "the reunion thing was fun,
but now it's time to get a little creative." On July 4, Faith No More played
their first show in two years at [Hyde Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London "Hyde
Park, London") in London, supporting [Black Sabbath](/wiki/Black_Sabbath
"Black Sabbath").[48] At that show, Faith No More debuted two new songs
"Motherfucker" and "Superhero" (also known by fans as "Leader of
Men").[49][50] On August 20, the band posted "The Reunion Tour is over; in
2015 things are going to change." These tweets led to speculation that the
band was working on new material.[51][52] On August 30, Gould said that the
band is "considering doing something new", and may begin work on a new studio
album at some point in the not-too-distant future, explaining, "to do
something creative would be a really good thing to do."[53] On September 2,
Bill Gould revealed to _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_
that the band had begun work on a new album.[54][55] Faith No More headlined
the final edition of Australia's
[Soundwave](/wiki/Soundwave_\(Australian_music_festival\) "Soundwave
\(Australian music festival\)") in February and March 2015.[56] The band
released their seventh studio album, _[Sol
Invictus](/wiki/Sol_Invictus_\(album\) "Sol Invictus \(album\)")_ , in May
2015.[4] The songs on the album were influenced by [The
Cramps](/wiki/The_Cramps "The Cramps"), [Link Wray](/wiki/Link_Wray "Link
Wray") and [Siouxsie and the Banshees](/wiki/Siouxsie_and_the_Banshees
"Siouxsie and the Banshees").[57] Speaking to
_[Revolver](/wiki/Revolver_\(magazine\) "Revolver \(magazine\)")_ , Gould
described the song "Cone of Shame" as "blues-based rock and roll". Describing
the song "Matador", he said: "parts of it remind me of the first Siouxsie and
the Banshees album. We used real pianos and that brings this organic quality
to it to the music".[57] The second single from the album, "Superhero", was
shared by the band on March 1, 2015.[58]

In a June 2016 interview, guitarist Jon Hudson stated that he has been
"working on a few ideas" for the next Faith No More album, and added that
"it's something that [he] wanted to focus on after the tour
ended."[59][60][61] When asked about the prospect of more music from Faith No
More, Patton told Australian newspaper _[The Sydney Morning
Herald](/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald "The Sydney Morning Herald")_ , "I
don't know whether or not we're going to attack it, but there is some stuff we
wrote around the time of the last one and said, 'Why don't we save this for
the next record?'. So we'll see."[62]

In August 2016, the band performed two concerts with former lead singer [Chuck
Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley") to celebrate the reissue of their
debut album _[We Care a Lot](/wiki/We_Care_a_Lot "We Care a Lot")_.[63] The
band was billed as "Chuck Mosley & Friends" for the two shows and featured the
lineup of Mosley, Mike Bordin, Billy Gould, Jon Hudson and Roddy Bottum.[64]

In a September 2017 interview on _[Full Metal Jackie
Radio](/wiki/Full_Metal_Jackie "Full Metal Jackie")_ , Patton revealed that
Faith No More has been "on an extended break." He added that he does not rule
out more shows with the band, explaining, "If something happens, it'll happen
organically and naturally. But I kind of don't think it will. I kind of feel
like we've tipped the scales a little bit. But we'll see. Who knows? I've
learned my lesson not to say 'no.'"[65]

Former Faith No More singer [Chuck Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley")
died on November 9, 2017, due to "the disease of addiction." He was 57 years
old.[66]

## Musical style and
influences[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Musical style and influences")]

While Faith No More's music is generally considered as [alternative
metal](/wiki/Alternative_metal "Alternative metal"),[67] [experimental
rock](/wiki/Experimental_rock "Experimental rock"),[68][69] and [funk
metal](/wiki/Funk_metal "Funk metal"),[70][71][72][73][74] as Faith No Man,
their sound was described as [post-punk](/wiki/Post-punk "Post-punk").[75] The
band's first single from 1983, "[Quiet in Heaven/Song of
Liberty](/wiki/Quiet_in_Heaven/Song_of_Liberty "Quiet in Heaven/Song of
Liberty")", was labelled as a "solid [post-punk](/wiki/Post-punk "Post-
punk")/pre-[goth](/wiki/Gothic_rock "Gothic rock") single."[76] During their
tenure with [Chuck Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley") in the
mid-1980s, [Billy Gould](/wiki/Billy_Gould "Billy Gould") stated the band were
in a "weird spot", as their eclectic sound didn't fit in with the burgeoning
[hardcore punk](/wiki/Hardcore_punk "Hardcore punk") and [alternative
rock](/wiki/Alternative_rock "Alternative rock") movements of the era.[77]
Upon Mike Patton's arrival in 1989, the band began to expand their sound range
even further, merging disparate genres such as [synthpop](/wiki/Synthpop
"Synthpop"),[78] [thrash metal](/wiki/Thrash_metal "Thrash metal")[22] and
[carousel music](/wiki/Circus_music "Circus music")[22] on _The Real Thing_.
_[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ states that during the
1990s, the band were "too heavy for the [post-grunge](/wiki/Post-grunge "Post-
grunge") pop hits of [The Verve](/wiki/The_Verve "The Verve") and [Third Eye
Blind](/wiki/Third_Eye_Blind "Third Eye Blind") [and] too arty to work
comfortably with the [nu metal](/wiki/Nu_metal "Nu metal") knuckle-draggers
they spawned."[67] Over the course of their career, they have experimented
with [heavy metal](/wiki/Heavy_metal_music "Heavy metal music"),
[funk](/wiki/Funk "Funk"), [hip hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music"),
[progressive rock](/wiki/Progressive_rock "Progressive rock"),[79]
[alternative rock](/wiki/Alternative_rock "Alternative rock"), [hardcore
punk](/wiki/Hardcore_punk "Hardcore punk"), [polka](/wiki/Polka "Polka"),
[easy listening](/wiki/Easy_listening "Easy listening"), [jazz](/wiki/Jazz
"Jazz"), [samba](/wiki/Samba "Samba"),[80] [ska](/wiki/Ska "Ska"),[81] [bossa
nova](/wiki/Bossa_nova "Bossa nova"),[82] [hard rock](/wiki/Hard_rock "Hard
rock"), [pop](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music"),[83] [soul](/wiki/Soul_music "Soul
music"),[84] [gospel](/wiki/Gospel_music "Gospel music"),[85] and [lounge
music](/wiki/Lounge_music "Lounge music").[86]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Ugly in the Morning" (1995)](/wiki/File:Faith_No_More_Ugly_in_the_Morning_sample.ogg "File:Faith No More Ugly in the Morning sample.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/b/bb/Faith_No_More_Ugly_in_the_Morning_sample.ogg) 30 second sample of the _King for a Day... Fool for a Lifetime_ song "Ugly in the Morning". It is one of many Faith No More songs predominantly influenced by heavy metal.

Faith No More's lyrics have been described as "bizarrely humorous". When
interviewed about his lyrics, Patton responded, "I think that too many people
think too much about my lyrics. I am more a person who works more with the
sound of a word than with its meaning. Often I just choose the words because
of the rhythm, not because of the meaning".[87]

Bordin acknowledged certain bands as early influences, including [Killing
Joke](/wiki/Killing_Joke "Killing Joke"), [PiL](/wiki/Public_Image_Ltd "Public
Image Ltd"), [Black Sabbath](/wiki/Black_Sabbath "Black Sabbath"), and
[Theatre of Hate](/wiki/Theatre_of_Hate "Theatre of Hate")[88], and upon
reforming, Faith No More returned to their early [post-punk](/wiki/Post-punk
"Post-punk")/[goth](/wiki/Gothic_rock "Gothic rock") influences on [Sol
Invictus](/wiki/Sol_Invictus_\(album\) "Sol Invictus \(album\)")[89].

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Legacy")]

In a 2015 article by [Artistdirect](/wiki/Artistdirect "Artistdirect"), [Duff
McKagan](/wiki/Duff_McKagan "Duff McKagan"), [Chino Moreno](/wiki/Chino_Moreno
"Chino Moreno"), [Serj Tankian](/wiki/Serj_Tankian "Serj Tankian"), [Corey
Taylor](/wiki/Corey_Taylor "Corey Taylor"), [Max Cavalera](/wiki/Max_Cavalera
"Max Cavalera") and [Jonathan Davis](/wiki/Jonathan_Davis "Jonathan Davis")
praised the band for their significance and influence.[90]
[Nirvana](/wiki/Nirvana_\(band\) "Nirvana \(band\)") bassist, and co-founder,
[Krist Novoselic](/wiki/Krist_Novoselic "Krist Novoselic") cited Faith No More
as a band that "paved the way for Nirvana" in the late 1980s.[91] [Robert
Plant](/wiki/Robert_Plant "Robert Plant"), singer of [Led
Zeppelin](/wiki/Led_Zeppelin "Led Zeppelin"), mentioned the then [Chuck
Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley")-led Faith No More as one of his
current favorite bands in a 1988 interview with _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_.[70] Plant and Faith No More
subsequently toured together following _The Real Thing '_s release.[92] [Scott
Ian](/wiki/Scott_Ian "Scott Ian") of [Anthrax](/wiki/Anthrax_\(American_band\)
"Anthrax \(American band\)") has also named Faith No More as one of his
favorite bands.[93][94]

[Corey Taylor](/wiki/Corey_Taylor "Corey Taylor") (frontman for both
[Slipknot](/wiki/Slipknot_\(band\) "Slipknot \(band\)") and [Stone
Sour](/wiki/Stone_Sour "Stone Sour")) told [Loudwire](/wiki/Loudwire
"Loudwire") in 2015 that if it wasn't for Faith No More, he "wouldn't be here
today." While recovering from an attempted suicide at his grandmother's house,
he saw the band perform "Epic" live on the [1990 MTV Video Music
Awards](/wiki/1990_MTV_Video_Music_Awards "1990 MTV Video Music Awards") and
the performance inspired him to begin writing and performing music again.[95]

They were voted No. 52 on [VH1](/wiki/VH1 "VH1")'s "100 Greatest Artists of
Hard Rock".[96] The band is credited for inventing the [alternative
metal](/wiki/Alternative_metal "Alternative metal") genre which began in the
1980s and that fuses [metal](/wiki/Heavy_metal_music "Heavy metal music") with
other genres, including [alternative rock](/wiki/Alternative_rock "Alternative
rock").[97] Tim Grierson of [About.com](/wiki/About.com "About.com") said the
band "helped put alternative metal on the map."[98] Faith No More has also
been credited for influencing [nu metal](/wiki/Nu_metal "Nu metal") bands,
such as [Limp Bizkit](/wiki/Limp_Bizkit "Limp Bizkit"), [Korn](/wiki/Korn
"Korn"), and [Sevendust](/wiki/Sevendust "Sevendust"),[99] primarily due to
the popularity of "[Epic](/wiki/Epic_\(Faith_No_More_song\) "Epic \(Faith No
More song\)")", and other early material that featured rap and rock
crossovers. [Papa Roach](/wiki/Papa_Roach "Papa Roach") vocalist [Jacoby
Shaddix](/wiki/Jacoby_Shaddix "Jacoby Shaddix"), a self-confessed fan of the
band, stated in a 2015 interview "They fused some of that hip-hop and rock
together. They were one of the earliest bands to do that, and definitely
pioneers to a whole genre. If you listen to Korn, if you listen to how the
bass and the drums lock up, it's quite similar to how Faith No More was doing
it in their early years."[100]

Faith No More have been covered by prominent metal acts such as [36
Crazyfists](/wiki/36_Crazyfists "36 Crazyfists"),[101]
[Apocalyptica](/wiki/Apocalyptica "Apocalyptica"),[102] [Atreyu](/wiki/Atreyu
"Atreyu"),[103] [Between the Buried and Me](/wiki/Between_the_Buried_and_Me
"Between the Buried and Me"),[104] [Disturbed](/wiki/Disturbed_\(band\)
"Disturbed \(band\)"),[105] [Five Finger Death
Punch](/wiki/Five_Finger_Death_Punch "Five Finger Death Punch"),[106]
[Helloween](/wiki/Helloween "Helloween"),[107] [Ill Niño](/wiki/Ill_Ni%C3%B1o
"Ill Niño"),[108] Korn,[109] [Machine Head](/wiki/Machine_Head_\(band\)
"Machine Head \(band\)"),[110] Papa Roach,[111]
[Redemption](/wiki/Redemption_\(band\) "Redemption \(band\)"),[112]
[Revocation](/wiki/Revocation_\(band\) "Revocation \(band\)"),[113]
[Sentenced](/wiki/Sentenced "Sentenced"),[114] [Slaves on
Dope](/wiki/Slaves_on_Dope "Slaves on Dope")[115] and [Trail of
Tears](/wiki/Trail_of_Tears_\(band\) "Trail of Tears \(band\)").[116] In 2002,
a tribute album titled _[Tribute of the
Year](/wiki/Tribute_of_the_Year:_A_Tribute_to_Faith_No_More "Tribute of the
Year: A Tribute to Faith No More")_ (a reference to Faith No More's _[Album of
the Year](/wiki/Album_of_the_Year_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "Album of the Year
\(Faith No More album\)")_) was released by [Underground
Inc.](/wiki/Underground_Inc. "Underground Inc.") It featured 30 Faith No More
songs covered by mostly unknown independent [hardcore](/wiki/Hardcore_punk
"Hardcore punk"), [industrial](/wiki/Industrial_metal "Industrial metal") and
alternative metal acts.[117]

The band and their 1989[note1] single
"[Epic](/wiki/Epic_\(Faith_No_More_song\) "Epic \(Faith No More song\)")" have
frequently been cited as an example of an '80s or '90s [one-hit
wonder](/wiki/One-hit_wonder "One-hit wonder").[118][119][120] _Flavorwire_
stated in 2014 "Although the band always had a loyal fan base and Patton
remains an indie hero, they only cracked the Billboard Hot 100 once, with
Epic." Others have noted that after "Epic"'s success, the band still managed
to remain highly popular in regions outside North America: including
Australia, South America, Europe and the UK.[121] The band's original final
record _Album of the Year_ notably experienced high sales in countries such as
Australia (where it went platinum),[122] New Zealand and Germany, while being
deemed a critical and commercial failure in their native USA.

### Relationship with Red Hot Chili
Peppers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Faith_No_More&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Relationship with Red Hot Chili Peppers")]

Main article: [Anthony Kiedis § Feud with Mike
Patton](/wiki/Anthony_Kiedis#Feud_with_Mike_Patton "Anthony Kiedis")

After the release of _[The Real
Thing](/wiki/The_Real_Thing_\(Faith_No_More_album\) "The Real Thing \(Faith No
More album\)")_ , Faith No More developed somewhat of a rivalry with fellow
Californian [funk rock](/wiki/Funk_rock "Funk rock") group [Red Hot Chili
Peppers](/wiki/Red_Hot_Chili_Peppers "Red Hot Chili Peppers"), whom they had
previously played with on [The Uplift Mofo Party
Tour](/wiki/The_Uplift_Mofo_Party_Tour "The Uplift Mofo Party
Tour").[123][124] Singer [Anthony Kiedis](/wiki/Anthony_Kiedis "Anthony
Kiedis") accused [Mike Patton](/wiki/Mike_Patton "Mike Patton") of stealing
his "style" in the "[Epic](/wiki/Epic_\(Faith_No_More_song\) "Epic \(Faith No
More song\)")" music video.[125][124] He told _[Kerrang!](/wiki/Kerrang!
"Kerrang!")_ magazine "My [drummer](/wiki/Chad_Smith "Chad Smith") says he’s
gonna kidnap [Patton], shave his hair off and cut off one of his feet, just so
he’ll be forced to find a style of his own".[124] In a separate interview, he
clarified his comment, remarking "I love _The Real Thing_ , and I liked his
vocals on that record. I mean, when I heard the record I noticed subtle
similarities, but when I saw that video it was like, 'Wait a second here, what
the fuck?.'"[125] [Roddy Bottum](/wiki/Roddy_Bottum "Roddy Bottum") responded
by saying "To me, our band sounds nothing like Red Hot Chili Peppers. If
you're talking about long hair, rapping with his shirt off, then yeah, I can
see similarities. But beyond that, I can't see any. I haven't talked to them
since this whole thing started. We're really good friends with that band and
i'd like to think they're doing it... like as a favour".[126] Mike Patton
finally addressed the allegations from Kiedis in 1990, commenting that "It
just kind of came out of the blue. It doesn't bother me a bit. I got a real
big kick out of it to tell you the truth. I mean, if he's gonna talk about me
in interviews, that's fine - it's free press! Either he's feeling inadequate
or old or I don't know, but I have no reason to talk shit about him."[127]
Later in 2001, Patton also theorized that "I think Anthony, deep down, feels
like I'm a better dancer than he is. I think I shake my booty just a little
bit fresher than he does. And if he would stop doing drugs I think he could
outdance me. Maybe one day we'll have a [breakoff](/wiki/Breakdancing
"Breakdancing"), just breakdance."[128]

Following a period of silence, the feud between Patton and Kiedis quickly
escalated again in 1999 with Patton's other band [Mr. Bungle](/wiki/Mr._Bungle
"Mr. Bungle"), culminating in an infamous Halloween show during 1999 in which
Patton (dressed as Kiedis) and his bandmates parodied the Red Hot Chili
Peppers and their hit singles.[124] The performance was in response to getting
kicked off a series of lucrative festival gigs shared with Red Hot Chili
Peppers, due to Kiedis's staunch refusal to perform with Mike Patton.[124]

Despite this, other members of both groups appear to have remained on good
terms since the initial controversy. Regarding the perceived conflict, Red Hot
Chili Peppers bassist [Flea](/wiki/Flea_\(musician\) "Flea \(musician\)")
stated "There was never any fight between us, that was a bunch of bullshit
created by the media. I mean I think they're a good band. Maybe there was some
things said between [Anthony](/wiki/Anthony_Kiedis "Anthony Kiedis") and the
singer [Patton], but it all means nothing to me. Those guys in the band are
nice people and there's no fight."[129] At a 2014 show in
[Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn"), the band also notably covered a portion
of the [Chuck Mosley](/wiki/Chuck_Mosley "Chuck Mosley")-era song "[We Care a
Lot](/wiki/We_Care_a_Lot_\(song\) "We Care a Lot \(song\)")".[124]

[Fox News](/wiki/Fox_News "Fox News") commentator [Greg
Gutfeld](/wiki/Greg_Gutfeld "Greg Gutfeld") attracted media attention in 2016
when he stated "You’re either a Faith No More fan, or a Red Hot Chili Peppers
fan. You cannot love Mike Patton and Anthony Kiedis, because they are two
different people. You have to love Mike Patton, you cannot love Anthony
Kiedis. So that is why the Red Hot Chili Peppers are the worst band in the
universe, because Faith No More is the greatest band in the
universe."[130][131]
